children.subject:
This is going to be qualitatively very different from a very structured course like 16B with weekly homeworks, discussions, etc. Students will be expected to have a lot of self motivation, to engage with the material, and to really put a lot of effort into their projects. So, I think that about 12ish hours per week on average is what you should expect to be putting in. It really depends a lot on the projects, but this isn't a do-it-all-in-three-nights kind of project.

For example, one kind of project that I want for sure to have at least one team on (with HCI background) is to develop a human-playable networked game so that we can see how humans can learn how to collaborate/coordinate with strangers playing alongside them. If a team was to make a simple framework to make such games, make a game within that framework that exhibited the kinds of phenomena that we'll see in the DARPA challenge, had people play that game using say Mechanical Turk or some other platform by which we could have multiple people play the game to collect some data, and then analyzed that data to say something about collaborative intelligence --- this would be a solid A project. If the framework was made in a way that also let us drop in some AIs to see how they play against people, this would be a solid A+.  This work could then turn into a paper and further research down the line if the students want to. 

Another kind of project that is still fine for the course would be a replication plus plus type study --- where a group replicates a result like the recent Google paper on learning encryption and then augmented it to see if a similar neural network can learn to modulate and error-correct alongside. So lots of flexibility here. 

Over the course of a semester, this kind of thing I think is very reasonable to do with a team of 3 students working together. We might allow some mixed grad-student/undergrad teams as well. This way, a willingness to work hard in implementation, learn things well on your own in a group (talking to me and your fellow students along the way) and learn even more while you do so is enough to allow an undergrad to participate.

How much work would this be, say, compared to your offering of 16B last semester?

This class sounds very interesting, but I don't want my life to RIP, so I need to schedule accordingly.
3 units, but those are EECS units :-)
How many units will this be?

This should be fine, especially if you are willing to work in a team with others whose skills complement your own. 

If the course is oversubscribed, I will select students so that I have the best mix of diverse backgrounds to help the course as a whole succeed. I wouldn't want a classroom filled with only one kind of student. The problems here are new and challenging, and I want this course to actually help move the ball forward in terms of understanding and research. This takes different points of view.
Perfect. Is there a application already available to apply to enroll in the course?
Just register and we will sort out applications closer to the start of Spring term.
Any idea what date the apps come out?

I'm very intrigued by this course and am really interested in taking it. However, my background is primarily in Math and Statistics, and my experience in CS is largely restricted to AI/ML/basic theory. Do you think this course might prove too inaccessible for someone with such a background? I have extensive experience with self-learning and a pretty strong work ethic, so I'd be willing to fill any small gaps in my knowledge on my own; just would like an idea as to how small/large those gaps might be.
Found it.
For anyone else who has trouble finding it, if you add the CS 194 class, it allows you to pick which section that you want if you click the Options button.
Can't seem to find it on CalCentral (classic). Is there a course number to enroll?

Realistically, the lower-division 16A,16B,70 plus 170 is probably sufficient to bring your math up to the level needed to follow. I'd like students to have one of: 160, 168/122, or 189. This way, I am more confident that you can find a project path that works for you. If you took 290S with Prof. Ramchandran, then that is certainly more than sufficient, and certainly not required. 

I want to have a diverse group of backgrounds for maximum creativity.
What kind of pre-reqs or experience do we need?

Yes. If there is more demand than seats in the course, then I will select on the basis of applications, not first-come first-serve. The goal is to maximize the overall creativity of the course as a whole. 

It is hard to say how likely anything is because this course has never been offered before and it is designed to be on the cutting edge.

Hi Professor Sahai - 

Would you recommend using Phase 2 units or to wait until adjustment period to add the class?
There is no point in using scarce units since the application process won't take when you added into account as more than a tie breaker.
When would you be reviewing the applications? I just saw this announcement, and am now hoping to add this course during the adjustment period. Would that be too late?

Hey Professor Sahai - 

Should I add myself to the waitlist for the class during adjustment period because calcentral currently lists the class as having no available seats?

Does the application process mean that even though you may be enrolled right now, you may get dropped later if too many students with your background/experience sign up? I have limited Phase 2 units so just wondering how likely it is that I will stay in the course.

As of now, consider this a one-off course.

Certainly the content will evolve if I ever offer this again, hopefully because the next course will get to study the results obtained by the group of students in this offering. The goal here is to substantively move the needle on the understanding of this area over the span of the semester.
Seems interesting. Is there a plan to present this class in any future semesters?

The most on-point paper conceptually is one from Madhu Sudan (Berkeley alum, former MIT, former MSR, now at Harvard) but it uses a computational complexity framework that is not quite a perfect fit for the deeper issues here.

There are also papers in evolutionary biology on the evolution of cooperation.

"Can we make agents that can learn to collaborate with each other without such agents having to be codesigned from the start? This is an emerging research frontier." 

Seems like an interesting question - are there any papers that you can point us to that address that question specifically or perhaps indirectly? I'm sure, many of us would love to read something to get more context.
Is there some sort of waitlist we can signup for to be notified when the application process opens?
Any updates on the application?

Here is the application form: https://goo.gl/forms/NmPwpiBWKxt0yZZo1

In case you missed the first lecture of the course. All undergrads must fill out the application so that the course has the right mix of diverse perspectives and backgrounds.

history.content:
Dear students,

I am going to be offering a special topics course this Spring. It will be held MW 1-2:30pm in 310 Soda. 

This should be a room-shared 194 and 294 pair. This is open to undergrads and grad students. 

At some point, it will show up on the campus systems.

194 Course Description:

This research/project-oriented course is about bringing artificial intelligence techniques based on machine learning and adaptation to the problem of collaboration rather than competition. Can we make agents that can learn to collaborate with each other without such agents having to be codesigned from the start? This is an emerging research frontier. To make things concrete, we will use the new DARPA Spectrum Collaboration Challenge as a key example. In the last decade, DARPA challenges were instrumental in kicking self-driving car technology into high gear. This new challenge aims to do the same for collaborative intelligence. Berkeley is going to be fielding a team in this challenge next year.
The hope is that many of the course projects will evolve into research papers, and if desired, continue into undergrad summer research positions that could go on through next year. 
 
Students do not require a wireless background to participate, as we will do a quick pass through the basics of wireless communication and networking as a part of this course. Students will have to present papers as a group, but the majority of the grade will be based on group projects (students will have wide leeway to come up with these, and I will also have some suggestions) and the course is open to a diverse set of backgrounds. If the course is oversubscribed, we will be selecting students to get a good mix of backgrounds. In particular, students with a background in human computer interaction are particularly welcomed, as are students with backgrounds in networking and those with a background in learning. 
UPDATE: 
Here is the application form: https://goo.gl/forms/NmPwpiBWKxt0yZZo1
history.subject: Special Topics CS 294/194-133: Collaborative Intelligent Agents and The DARPA Spectrum Challenge

history.subject: Special Topics CS 294/194-133: "Collaborative Intelligent Agents and The DARPA Spectrum Challenge"
